today at reinvent so I guess happy birthday Amazon MQ one year and since
then thousands of customers have migrated to Amazon MQ what it is is it's a managed message broker service for
Apache ActiveMQ so one of the analogies I like to use is it's like RDS for
message brokers so just like RDS takes away the heavy lifting and management of the infrastructure for a sequel database
Amazon I'm cute too something very similar for message brokers that lets
you focus on your value-add and lets us manage the plumbing one of the things
customers told us they really love about Amazon MQ is the api compatibility so if
you're migrating existing applications or you just really want to have something that's compatible with with
other systems Amazon MQ provides that because it provides compatibility with JMS with NMS which is the dotnet version
of JMS it provides a wide range of other protocols like AMQP which is the
advanced Message Queuing protocol it's an industry standard and ISO standard also stomp text based with very
simple text based messaging protocol it also has WebSocket & MQTT so a wide
range of protocols and api's facilitates that compatibility the other thing
customers really love about amazon mq is it provides that high availability and durability so your applications remain
online obviously very important nobody likes their applications going offline so the way amazon mq does that is we
provide an active and standby broker they're in separate availability zones and as you all know availability zones
are physically separate infrastructure so if there's ever any issue with the broker itself or even an entire
availability zone the standby takes over and they're using shared storage so all messages are stored across multiple
availability zones and the active in standby broker of access to those messages so if there is a failover
you don't lose any messages the messages they persisted in in the shared storage
and just like RDS we do provide a single instance version as well which customers
often find useful for just development and test workloads or just if they want to just try out the service and
customers always love worryfree security it's again one of those things that doesn't you know add differentiation to
your application you want to just have the security there and an Amazon mq has a lot of features there so we provide
encryption in transit its enforce TLS so the transport is always encrypted for
all connections there's encryption at rest so the data that's persisted to that persistent
message store is encrypted at rest you can choose sorry it's actually fully
integrated with Amazon VPC so it's VPC enabled you can choose to have it a
public endpoint as well but that's optional so you can just maintain the broker within your VPC and block public
Internet access and of course you can have public endpoints you have security
groups that provide further guards against unwanted access those security groups act like a virtual firewall for
your message broker again very similar to yes or ec2 for those of you familiar with those services and then there's
queue and topic level authorizations so there's username and password access to queues and topics so you can decide
which applications you want to have access to the destinations or the queues and topics in ActiveMQ actually I didn't
mention I don't think that it's isn't I didn't the initial slide but this is an active in queue based broker so activemq
is an open source broker so we're actually hosting the open source version of ActiveMQ it's exactly the same as the
one you can download from the apache website without changes and we keep it up-to-date for you so we when there's
minor version updates or any new updates we make those available there's an automatic version upgrade capability
available as well so you can just choose to have your broker automatically upgrade when you new versions become
available one of the other great things
people love is obviously they've Adamas platform has a lot of capabilities and one of the nice things is the

queues and topics on the broker itself you can dive into logs we provide

cloud trail provides auditing you need for things like compliance and actually

utilization you can monitor queue depth you can monitor things like the number of subscribers on a queue or a topic and
of course you can use the that allows you to use the features of cloud watch things like alarms to notify you when
something goes wrong so you might have a maximum queue depth that you set and you can monitor that and and have an alarm
that then triggers an SNS notification like an email to you if something has gone wrong in cloud watch logs as I
mentioned is there to die a bit more deeply and cloud watch logs has a lot of powerful features I think some new ones
being introduced this week as well where you can pattern match on things that are
happening in the logs and again set alarms and notifications on those so lots of capabilities to help you manage
obviously we're managing a big portion of the broker for you so it's a it's a
nice capability we've talked a lot about the infrastructure management side of
things what about messaging itself so ActiveMQ is very feature-rich it contains all the features you expect
from a kind of a modern enterprise message broker message brokers have been around for a long time I think IBM MQ is
introduced in the in the mid-90s so this is not new technology and over that time a lot of features have been developed
and a lot of applications make use of these features so it's important if you're migrating to have those features
available in a message broker and so there's things like transient and persistent messaging so persistent
messaging where messages are stored to durable media to make sure that there's
no message loss transient messaging is where messages are just stored in memory and that can actually facilitate much
higher performance and lower latency there's things like local and distributed transactions so applications
use that when they want to ensure consistency with a database for example and ActiveMQ supports that of course
queues and topics are supported basic messaging constructs and they support
FIFO ordering so you can ensure that your messages arrive in order and exactly once there's
a concept of composite and virtual destinations so a composite destination
is think of it as a queue where you send to one named queue one virtual queue and
it actually sends to three physical cues or ten physical cues or however many you want so that's one cool idea the other
concept that activemq supports is virtual destinations a virtual queue or
a virtual topic really helps you with pub/sub kind of messaging model because it dynamically creates when a subscriber
subscribes to a topic it dynamically creates a queue for each subscriber what
else there's message filtering request reply model which is something that's part of the JMS specifications or it's
that it supports scheduling messages so you can schedule a message to be sent at a later time and we don't limit message
size we don't limit message retention we don't recommend retaining messages for really really long times it's not a
database it's a it's a messaging system and messages are supposed to flow through but we don't limit that so that's that's useful for a lot of use
cases as well now ActiveMQ works by
providing long-lived protocol connections between producers and consumers and the broker so it's
it's not a rest-based or HTTP based model it provides actually those long-lived protocol connections over TCP
and one of the cool things about that is it really facilitates that low latency so we see less than 10 millisecond
latency between producing a message and consuming it single-digit latency and particularly
with transient messaging where the messages are are simply stored in memory
and not written to disk that really facilitates that low latency and Ben's going to talk about a really practical
